thread.title: Rail fan fantasy: Driving a historic steam locomotive
thread.title_full: Rail fan fantasy: Driving a historic steam locomotive

author: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY
title: Rail fan fantasy: Driving a historic steam locomotive
text:
The Cumbres & Toltec steam train connecting Colorado and New Mexico has a famous history, and you can ride the same rails as Indiana Jones, and even stay in his childood home. Trevor Hughes/USA TODAY
Locomotive 488 smokes and steams as it crests Cumbres Pass on the historic steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY )
776 CONNECT 12 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE CHAMA, N.M.-- Hands sweating in borrowed leather gloves, I slowly ease the oversized brass lever toward me with an odd-sounding combination of brute strength and finesse.
Ronnie Lopez nods encouragingly. "Just a little more," he says, his own gloved hand ready to grab the hot metal control if I mess up.
But then, ever so slowly, the 130-ton locomotive attached to that lever begins to chug forward, great clouds of coal smoke puffing from its stack. Lopez relaxes slightly, his other hand never far from the brake.
Inside the cab of this 1920s-era locomotive is a bewildering tangle of hydraulic and steam lines, levers, spigots and valves. None are labeled. All look important. And all are too hot to touch with bare hands.
The boiler up front is sitting at nearly 200 psi, a trainee fireman is shoveling great hunks of coal into the already-roaring firebox to keep the pressure up, and there's already all kinds of pressure on me.
I'm not nervous. Much.
The day before, this same locomotive, Locomotive 488, carried us on the 64-mile-long run from the farming community of Antonito, Colo., up and over Cumbres Pass and then down to the ranching town of Chama, N.M. Crossing Cumbres at 10,015 feet above sea level, the Cumbres & Toltec Scenic Railroad is the nation's longest and highest narrow-gauge railway.
Opened in 1880, the railroad carried silver ore, timber and livestock, along with passengers, on its 3-foot-wide tracks. Standard American train tracks are 4 feet, 8.5-inches wide, but narrower gauges allows trains to better climb in mountainous regions because the tracks can be more tightly curved in narrow areas.
The day I drive the train, professional engineers from the railroad are teaching a dozen men, most of them retirees, how to properly shovel coal into the firebox, make steam and then harness that power to drive the locomotive forward.
"They are not refined machines," says Bill Hobbs, a retired securities industry executive from Little Rock who's on his third four-day visit to the school. "The feeling of crude power is a big part of the attraction."
Attraction is the wrong word. Obsession is a more accurate one. These guys -- and it's virtually all guys -- are spending thousands of dollars to learn how to drive the trains owned jointly by a Colorado-New Mexico state trust and operated solely for excursions and education.
Engineer Jeff Stebbins inspects Locomotive 488 before he drives the steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train from Antonito, Colo., to Chama, N.M. By pulling back on the lever, the train's engineer feeds more steam into the engine's pistons, which accelerates the train. "New guys, they want to yank on it," Stebbins says. "You've just got to pump it." (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 pulls passenger cars on the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad as it climbs out of Antonito, Colo., toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Brakeman Greg Lawrence peers toward the front of the train. Part of Lawrence's job is monitoring the train for lost hydraulic brake connections, which could potentially detach and hang down beneath the cars ahead. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 sends aloft a heavy cloud of coal smoke as it steams out of Antonito, Colo., toward Chama, N. M., on the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A pall of coal smoke hangs over a valley following the passage of the train. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Engineer Jeff Stebbins stands atop a water tender as he refills a Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train from a trackside tank. The train's boiler uses coal to make steam from the water, and the tank must be refilled often when the train is climbing hard, as it does when it winds its way up Cumbres Pass on the Colorado border. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Conductor Alan Loomis is dwarfed by the train while it takes on water for its boiler. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 sends aloft a heavy cloud of coal smoke as it steams out of Antonito, Colo., toward Chama, N. M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Engineer Jeff Stebbins keeps one hand on the brake while fireman Jose Rodriguez looks back as the train pulls toward Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Fireman Jose Rodriguez's shovel, loaded with coal, blurs as he loads the firebox of a Cumbres & Toltec Railroad steam engine. The train burns coal to make steam, which then drives pistons connected to its drive wheels. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Fireman Jose Rodriguez takes a drink while on a break from shoveling coal as the train climbs up Cumbres Pass. When the train is heavily loaded and climbing a steep grade, firemen like Rodriquez must feed coal into the firebox almost constantly. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Fireman Jose Rodriguez takes a break from shoveling coal to watch the scenery as the train climbs up Cumbres Pass in southern Colorado. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Engineer Jeff Stebbins checks a water gauge on the steam engine's boiler. The train makes steam by burning coal. The steam then drives the engine's pistons, which turn its wheels. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Longtime steam train enthusiast William Warren, left, watches scenery pass as he rides the steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad toward Cumbres Pass. Warren, a retired safety engineer, estimates he's ridden 75 different kinds of trains, but prefers the power, sound and soul of steam, which he says "separates the men from the boys." (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The train steams past a rock outcropping that railroad workers say reminds them of a couple facing each other. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams into a rock tunnel, one of several tunnels on the route connecting Antonito, Colo., with Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Fireman Jose Rodriguez, left, and engineer Jeff Stebbins look down from their engine as it sends a heavy smoke plume into the air as it climbs the Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Two men examine the locomotive as children play on the tracks during a lunch stop on the route between Antonito, Colo., and Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Steam train enthusiast William Warren, 70, shows off his custom-embroidered jacket during the lunch stop. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Texan Russell Rawle, who with his wife likes to dress in period costume as they RV around America, takes a photo with his digital camera from the rear of the parlor car. Rawle, a retired aircraft worker, carries cards that advertise his services as a man able to fight wars, tame tigers, start revolutions or quell uprisings. He says, half-jokingly, that he and his wife are spending their kids' inheritance. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train heads down the Colorado side of Cumbres Pass after a lunch stop at Osier. The railroad offers full- and half-day excursions on the steam trains. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams over a trestle on its climb up Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Anglers test the trout waters of an alpine stream near the top of Cumbres Pass, as seen from a Cumbres & Toltec Railroad steam train. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams through an alpine meadow on its climb up Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Anglers are dwarfed by the western scenery in an alpine meadow near the top of Cumbres Pass, as seen from a Cumbres & Toltec Railroad steam train. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams through an alpine meadow on its climb up Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Passengers watch through the window as the train curves through an alpine meadow. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The train passes an historic water tank, where engines in years past would take on additional water before making the final climb to Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Elizabeth Rawle sits in the parlor carwith her husband, Russell. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The Rawles aren't affiliated with the railroad -- they just like to dress up and ride the steam train. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The train makes its way toward Cumbres Pass, near the Colorado-New Mexico border. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Passengers watch from the open-air gondola as the train steams up toward Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroadtrain makes its way toward Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroadtrain makes its way toward Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams and smokes as it makes the final ascent up toward Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The hill is so steep that railroad builders were forced to loop the track back on itself in this area -- the lower section of track is seen below the climbing train. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A sign marks the top of the Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train makes its descent into the valley from Cumbres Pass toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Passengers often see bear, elk, deer and foxes on the journey. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A water tank sits beside the tracks at Cresco. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The train rolls on from Cumbres Pass toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen People watch as the train pulls into the station at Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A parlor car attendant helps Elizabeth and Russell Rawle from the train after arriving in Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Workers at the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad's yard in Chama, N.M., prepare a steam train for its morning journey. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Steam pouring from a locomotive's funnel shines in the morning sun. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad locomotive steams as it begins to leave the Chama, N.M., yard on its morning journey. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 gets underway in the Chama, N.M., yard. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad locomotive steams past a water tower, with a coal tipple standing in the background, as it leaves the yard in Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen The now-unused station atop Cumbres Pass on the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A signboard shows the date of a commercial trip on the steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. The train today is run solely for sightseers or students learning how to drive steam locomotives. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 smokes and steams as it crests Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Students and an instructor watch from the caboose as the train backs up into a wye -- a Y-shaped section of track -- that allows the train to change directions. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 smokes and steams as it crests Cumbres Pass on the historic steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A student hangs off the back of a caboose as the train begins its descent from Cumbres Pass toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A freight car used by the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad bears the names of two other historic Colorado train routes. Trains still run on those routes, but they are standard-gauge trains, not narrow-gauge like the Cumbres & Toltec. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Steam obscures students learning how to operate a locomotive on the the historic steam-powered Cumbres & Toltec Railroad. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A train on the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad descends from Cumbres Pass toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A student in the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train school sits in the fireman's seat as the train descends Cumbres Pass toward Chama, N.M. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Locomotive 488 steams and smokes as it climbs the west side of Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A steam train on the Cumbres & Toltec Railroad passes a water tower that featured in the movie "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade." In the movie, a young Indy rides a circus train along this section of track, and swings on the water spout in an effort to escape his pursuers. Indy then runs into his father's house, which today is a bed-and-breakfast in Antonito, Colo. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Students learning how to drive a Cumbres & Toltec Railroad engine conduct a "blowdown," which vents steam from the boiler to quickly reduce pressure. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Several deep gorges flank the narrow-gauge tracks, and signs warn train passengers against throwing anything down. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A Cumbres & Toltec Railroad train steams up the New Mexico side of Cumbres Pass during a school for would-be train engineers. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A locomotive sends a cloud of smoke and steam into the air as it climbs the 4% grade out of Chama, N.M., on its way up Cumbres Pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen A train emerges from a snow shed atop Cumbres Pass before heading down to Chama, N.M. The shed provides shelter for the locomotive if it has to stay overnight on the pass. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY) Fullscreen A student-run train, right, sits on a siding as an excursion train filled with tourists ascends Cumbres Pass from the New Mexico side. The two trains can only "meet" at sidings. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen After turning around at the top, Locomotive 488 cruises back down Cumbres Pass as a student looks out the engineer's compartment. There's no windows in the cab because the boiler generates more than enough heat to keep the engineer and fireman warm. (Photo: Trevor Hughes, USA TODAY ) Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The railroad and its school are a significant economic driver for the two rural towns, but the small legion of devoted fans worry too few people know about the railway despite its pedigree. Instead, most people are are more familiar with the Durango & Silverton line, a few hours' drive away but much more accessible to passing tourists.
The two railways used to be connected as part of the larger Denver & Rio Grande Railway, which limped out of the Great Depression and shut down in the 1950s. The Cumbres & Toltec line struggled on through a short oil boom but was nearly abandoned by the late 1960s.
Railroad enthusiasts who couldn't bear the potential loss persuaded the governments of Colorado and New Mexico to take over, and a cadre of paid staff and devoted volunteers keep it running despite challenges that include the need to hand-make virtually every replacement part.
Neil Hague loves that idea. An aerospace engineer from Wichita, Hague is going through the engineer school for a fourth time, grinning widely as he takes the right-hand seat reserved for the train's driver.
"One hundred years ago, this is what I would have been working on instead of airplanes," he says.
The chugging locomotives draw fans most every day who chase them along the nearby road, pulling off at well-worn spots to snap photos as clouds of coal smoke and steam bellow from the stacks. Among the best-known amateur chasers are Fort Worth brothers Casey and Cody Akin, who a few years ago met the railway staff when they accidentally got their pickup stuck on a crossing.
On a recent day, the two, along with a friend and Casey's wife, Rachel, spend hours driving up and down Cumbres Pass to take photos they've taken dozens of times previously. Their dad introduced them to trains as kids.
"We pulled onto the main street and I saw that train and I was hooked," Casey Akin, 33, says.
The Akins, who run a trucking company, spend a week visiting the trains each year, not sure if that visit will be their last. They worry about the age of the men and women dedicated to operating the railroad, and fear it might one day just quit running.
"A lot of these older people, they were alive when steam was running for real," Casey Akin says. "The younger people, they've probably never even seen one."
That's probably true -- at least not in person. But millions of people have seen these trains before. They featured prominently in the 1989 movie Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade , in a sequence in which a young Indy fights baddies on a circus train.
That water spout he grabs onto? It's real and just outside Chama. And that house he runs into, where Henry Jones is carefully examining his Grail diary? That's real, too. The house in Antonito today is a family-run bed-and-breakfast where you can drift off to sleep in Indy's bedroom and be awoken by roosters and the train's steam whistle the next morning.
Sound is a major factor for steam enthusiasts. Russell Rawle, a Texan who dresses in period costume to ride, says you have to stand next to a steam train to fully appreciate it.
He's right. In comparison to soulless modern cars with fake engine noise piped into the passenger compartment, steam trains carry their power, controls and history right where you can feel it.
"You can feel it breathing," Rawle says. "It's a living, breathing thing."
If you go
Getting there: You can board the train from either Chama, N.M., or Antonito, Colo. Chama is about two hours north of Santa Fe, and about three hours north of Albuquerque, while Antonito is about a four-hour drive south of Denver. Many train enthusiasts ride the Cumbres & Toltec and then drive two hours northwest to Durango to ride the Durango & Silverton narrow-gauge steam train. Lodging options in both Antonito and Chama are limited, but in Antonito include the Indiana Jones House Bed & Breakfast.
Railroad excursions: Plan on spending a full day on the train. You can board in either Antonito or Chama, ride over Cumbres Pass, and then return via motor coach. You can also ride the coach over the pass first and take the train back, or ride one train up to the lunch stop at Osier, switch trains as they pass, and return to your starting point. The railroad also offers special excursion trains, including sunset rides and John Denver-tribute concerts held at 10,000 feet above sea level. Prices start at $95 for adults and $49 for kids for full-day rides, rising to $179 for adults in the parlor car, where passengers are greeted with fresh fruit and treated to complimentary cake and drinks. Snacks are available for purchase on the train. For more information call 1-888-286-2737 or visit cumbrestoltec.com/schedule-fares .
Fireman and Engineer Steam School Classes: Classes are filled for the remainder of the year. The four-day classes start at $2,250 for fireman school, which must be completed before moving onto engineer school, which costs $2,750. Classes are limited to 12 students at a time. An advanced class teaches railroad operations and dealing with runaway trains. That class costs $4,000, and both fireman and engineer classes must be completed first. For more information about the schools, call 1-888-286-2737 or email cwilliams@cumbrestoltec.com .
